topic_metadata.title: How can I load configuration and defined in another .typ file?

posts.name: Hyunbin Yoo
posts.cooked:
So far I have only used one .typ file per project. Now I would like to save repetitive configurations and load them with one # so that I don’t have to type the same thing multiple times when I have more than one .typ file in a project.

All of my .typ files start with the following:

#set page(
  paper: "us-letter",
  margin: 0.5in,
)
#set text(
  font: "New Computer Modern",
  size: 12pt
)

#let title = [
  (Insert Title Here)
]

#let print_title = {
  align(center, text(12pt)[
  *#title*
])
}

Is it possible to have a config.typ file that contains the above, which are all loaded with a single # at the start of another .typ file in the same project? Also, can title be manually overridden in the new .typ file as needed?
posts.raw:
So far I have only used one .typ file per project. Now I would like to save repetitive configurations and load them with one # so that I don't have to type the same thing multiple times when I have more than one .typ file in a project.

All of my .typ files start with the following:

```typ
#set page(
  paper: "us-letter",
  margin: 0.5in,
)
#set text(
  font: "New Computer Modern",
  size: 12pt
)

#let title = [
  (Insert Title Here)
]

#let print_title = {
  align(center, text(12pt)[
  *#title*
])
}
```

Is it possible to have a config.typ file that contains the above, which are all loaded with a single # at the start of another .typ file in the same project? Also, can title be manually overridden in the new .typ file as needed?

posts.cooked:
What you’re looking for is called a template. Here is the official Typst guide on templates:

Typst

Making a Template – Typst Documentation

Typst's tutorial.

Your example would become:
Main Typst file:

#import "template.typ": *
#show: template

#print_title([Template Test])

= Foo

#lorem(10)

template.typ:

#let print_title(title) = {
  align(center, text(12pt)[
  *#title*
  ])
}

#let template(doc) = {
  set page(
    paper: "us-letter",
    margin: 0.5in,
  )
  set text(
    font: "New Computer Modern",
    size: 12pt
  )
  
  doc
}
posts.raw:
What you're looking for is called a template.  Here is the official Typst guide on templates:
https://typst.app/docs/tutorial/making-a-template/

Your example would become:
Main Typst file:
```typ
#import "template.typ": *
#show: template

#print_title([Template Test])

= Foo

#lorem(10)
```
`template.typ`:
```typ
#let print_title(title) = {
  align(center, text(12pt)[
  *#title*
  ])
}

#let template(doc) = {
  set page(
    paper: "us-letter",
    margin: 0.5in,
  )
  set text(
    font: "New Computer Modern",
    size: 12pt
  )
  
  doc
}
```

posts.name: Hyunbin Yoo
posts.cooked: Thank you so much! Can I import a template from another project? That is, can I create a “global” template that can be imported by any project?
posts.raw: Thank you so much! Can I import a template from another project? That is, can I create a "global" template that can be imported by any project?

posts.cooked:
I believe the way to do this is make a local package. Forum user Eric posted an answer about this here:

Can I define a dedicated/default Template folder? Questions
You can store your templates in a local package namespace. For this, you need to put your template package in a specific directory, depending on your operating system: Windows: %APPDATA%\typst\packages\<namespace>\<name>\<version> macOS: ~/Library/Application Support/typst/packages/<namespace>/<name>/<version> Linux: ~/.local/share/typst/packages/<namespace>/<name>/<version> (or via the environment variable $XDG_DATA_HOME, see the above link) For <namespace>, you can use whatever you want, bu…
posts.raw:
I believe the way to do this is make a local package.  Forum user Eric posted an answer about this here:
https://forum.typst.app/t/can-i-define-a-dedicated-default-template-folder/925/3?u=gezepi

posts.name: Hyunbin Yoo
posts.cooked: Understood! So if I wanted to do this in the web app, would the only option be to publicly publish my template as part of a package?
posts.raw: Understood! So if I wanted to do this in the web app, would the only option be to publicly publish my template as part of a package?

posts.cooked:
That’s a good question that I don’t know the answer to.
Publishing a package would certainly work, but it seems overkill to me. Plus it could be an information security problem, depending on what info is included in your template.
posts.raw:
That's a good question that I don't know the answer to.
Publishing a package would certainly work, but it seems overkill to me.  Plus it could be an information security problem, depending on what info is included in your template.
